Award.AwardTitle: Fingerprinting Type I Supernovae: Quantifying Their Diversity and Sharpening Their Utility
Award.AbstractNarration:
Exploding stars that show no Hydrogen in their spectra are called Type 1 supernovovae. They are vital for many areas of astrophysics. The most famous sub-class are the Type Ia, which have yielded exciting results about the accelerating expansion of the universe. However, for the next step in precision cosmology, identifications are needed of Type Ia at very large distances, which is difficult, because they are easily confused with other types of Type I supernovae, namely Type Ib/c. This survey will study the observed differences between these supernova types to eliminate mistaken classifications and thus enable a better understanding of the acceleration of our universe at earlier stages in its expansion, billions of years in the past.

While Type Ia are the result of thermonuclear explosions of a C-O white dwarf in a binary system, Type Ib/c are core-collapse explosions from massive stars, which have been removed of their outermost H layer. Type Ib/c observations cannot be used to derive accurate distance measurements; however, because their spectra look like Type 1a supernovae, they can contaminate large supernova surveys. This award is to conduct a thorough statistical analysis of optical spectra and lightcurves (records of light emitted over time) of thousands of supernovae in order to distinguish between Type Ia supernova and Types 1b and 1c and remove the impostors from the surveys. This project will develop the tools needed to quickly and automatically identify and remove Type 1b/c supernovae from surveys. The PI will provide these tools and methods to the community for future observations with other telescopes, such as the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), which is expected to yield thousands of new supernova candidates per night. The data will also be used to test models of core-collapse explosions of massive stars, which will improve knowledge of stellar evolution. The PI will train and mentor a graduate student and undergraduate student in research, and she will also collaborate with an external organization to recruit a promising high school student from an underrepresented group in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM).

The work will be done through a two-pronged approach: 1) utilizing the traditional spectral template approach with well-established algorithms, and then 2) employing Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to derive eigenspectrum bases, which if found in a robust fashion, can be easily used to construct average spectral time-series templates and to identify any new classification schemes within the available data. In addition, the PI will clarify the link between SN spectral classification for SN Ib/c, including those connected with Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRBs), and their purported stellar progenitors by testing for hidden He in SN Ic. This will be done by comparing observed spectra and light curves of a large set of SN Ib/c, for the first time, with those predicted from two competing models. The PI will use spectra and lightcurves of over 5800 supernova explosions that are recently published (such as WISeREP and SUSPECT) or are in-hand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has resulted in 13 publications and 5 code/data product releases so far, of which 8 are lead by NYU grad students.

Exploding stars are the most powerful explosions in the universe, and understanding which kinds of stellar systems give rise to which kinds of explosions, i.e., Supernovae (SNe) of various types, is a formidable task.  Since SNe can be seen over large cosmological distances, release elements heavier than Helium, and leave behind extreme objects like Black Holes, they are intrinsically fascinating objects, as well as crucial tools for many areas of astrophysics. Moreover, correctly classifying these transients, whose observed signature changes over time, is the first and most important task for understanding these explosions and their hotly debated progenitor stars and explosion mechanisms, as well as for using them as powerful tools for cosmology, i.e., for measuring the expansion of the universe as a function of cosmic time. 

These are the two fundamental areas that the NSF funded project by PI Modjaz encompasses. She and her group analyzed the visible-light signatures from SNe, as captured by telescopes in form of spectra, that is, light as a function of wavelength, Spectra are crucial since they reveal the chemical elements present in the explosions and in the progenitor star, as well as the velocities for the different layers of elements, which can change over time and provide a tomographic view, like a CAT scan of the interior of the exploding star.

The project answered fundamental questions about the properties of Stripped Supernovae, which are explosions from massive stars that have had their outer layers of Hydrogen and Helium stripped to various degrees before explosion and whose stripping mechanisms are debated.

The project's outcome has resulted in a large advancement in the world-wide efforts for classification. Since the observed signatures of one subtype of these explosions, called Type Ic SN (SN Ic), can masquerade as those of another type of explosion, called Type Ia SN, which is utilized for cosmological studies, it is important to distinguish them - and only a comprehensive comparison library may tell them apart.  The project (in a series of published papers) released the template spectra of almost 100 Stripped SNe for the widely-used SN classification code SNID and thus more than doubled the number of such SNe in the SNID library. Since then, many different SN groups around the world have used their spectral templates to classify new SNe correctly, in particular to remove the contaminating SNe Ic from SNe Ia samples and to correctly classify SNe connected with Gamma-ray Bursts (GRBs), which are extreme explosions that can be seen across cosmic time up to 13 billion light years, out to a time when the universe was very young. In addition the project developed the first quantitative data-driven technique in the world to classify and characterize different kinds of transients, in particular Stripped-Envelope Supernovae, including those connected with GRBs, using state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, also known as artificial intelligence.

The project has tackled the hotly debated field of the progenitor question, namely the question of which stars give rise to which kinds of explosions, by carefully analyzing the largest data set of Stripped SNe in the world and by comparing the observational trends with those predicted by various competing models.   In addition she demonstrates that two specific sub-types of Stripped SNe are not markedly different in composition, but rather constitute a continuum of Hydrogen envelope amounts. These insights are of great interest for theorists who model the composition of stars before explosion and the mechanisms by which the envelopes could have been stripped, which is still an outstanding question.

 

The project has quantified the spectroscopic diversity of various classes of Stripped SNe by introducing a novel way of characterizing them by their statistical properties, In addition she has developed a completely new method of measuring velocities for the Stripped SNe of Type Ic-bl, which are observed to sometimes accompany GRBs

In addition to the exciting science insights, in terms of the methodology, the PI’s work sets a new and thorough standard in the field of Stripped SNe spectra and their analysis. This is the first time that such an analysis has been done in a statistically thorough fashion with the largest data set in the world, and her results will have large impact on a number of areas of astrophysics.

All the data products and code are publicly accessible on the group’s Github account.

 PI Modjaz and her group have engaged with the broader public via public talks, and media appearances aiming at improving public knowledge of astrophysics and demolishing incorrect stereotypes about scientists. Additional broader impact activities included training and mentoring of a minority undergraduate student and a female graduate student (leading to the first all-female paper in the SN field).
